options.label: A
options.text: To ride a bike with no hands

options.label: B
options.text: To ride a bike with the handlebars reversed

options.label: C
options.text: To ride a bike with the pedals removed

options.label: D
options.text: To ride a bike with a blindfold

multiple-choice.question: What was Destin's initial reaction when trying to ride the reversed bike?

options.label: A
options.text: He was able to ride it easily

options.label: B
options.text: He was frustrated but able to ride it after a few attempts

options.label: C
options.text: He was unable to ride it and became frustrated

options.label: D
options.text: He refused to try

multiple-choice.question: According to Destin, what is the relationship between knowledge and understanding?

options.label: A
options.text: Knowledge is the same as understanding

options.label: B
options.text: Knowledge is a prerequisite for understanding

options.label: C
options.text: Knowledge does not equal understanding

options.label: D
options.text: Understanding is not necessary for knowledge

multiple-choice.question: What is the term that Destin uses to describe the brain's ability to adapt and change?

options.label: A
options.text: Neural plasticity

options.label: B
options.text: Cognitive bias

options.label: C
options.text: Muscle memory

options.label: D
options.text: Algorithmic thinking

multiple-choice.question: How long did it take Destin's son to learn how to ride the reversed bike?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 day

options.label: B
options.text: 1 week

options.label: C
options.text: 2 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: 8 months

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Destin's experiment in Amsterdam?

options.label: A
options.text: He was able to ride a normal bike easily

options.label: B
options.text: He was unable to ride a normal bike at first, but eventually was able to

options.label: C
options.text: He was unable to ride a normal bike at all

options.label: D
options.text: He didn't try to ride a normal bike

multiple-choice.question: What did Destin learn from his experiment about cognitive bias?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is easy to overcome

options.label: B
options.text: That it is impossible to overcome

options.label: C
options.text: That it can be re-designated but not eliminated

options.label: D
options.text: That it only affects certain people

multiple-choice.question: What was the reaction of the people watching Destin try to ride a normal bike in Amsterdam?

options.label: A
options.text: They were supportive and encouraging

options.label: B
options.text: They were confused and didn't understand what was happening

options.label: C
options.text: They thought Destin was faking his inability to ride

options.label: D
options.text: They were angry and frustrated

multiple-choice.question: What is the title of the book that Destin recommends at the end of the video?

options.label: A
options.text: "An Astronaut's Guide to Life on Earth"

options.label: B
options.text: "The Art of Learning"

options.label: C
options.text: "The Power of Habit"

options.label: D
options.text: "The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People"

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message that Destin is trying to convey through his experiment and video?

options.label: A
options.text: That knowledge is the same as understanding

options.label: B
options.text: That cognitive bias is impossible to overcome

options.label: C
options.text: That truth is truth, regardless of our perceptions or biases

options.label: D
options.text: That learning is only possible through hands-on experience

title: The surprising reason you feel awful when you're sick - Marco A. Sotomayor

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary role of macrophages in the immune system when a pathogen enters the body?

options.label: A
options.text: To release cytokines to recruit more immune cells

options.label: B
options.text: To destroy viruses and infected cells

options.label: C
options.text: To transmit information to the brain stem

options.label: D
options.text: To produce prostaglandin E2

multiple-choice.question: What happens when cytokines travel to the hypothalamus in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The hypothalamus produces macrophages to fight infection

options.label: B
options.text: The hypothalamus sends signals to reduce body temperature

options.label: C
options.text: The hypothalamus produces prostaglandin E2 to gear up for war

options.label: D
options.text: The hypothalamus reduces the production of neurotransmitters

multiple-choice.question: A patient is experiencing a rise in body temperature, aches, and pains due to the flu. What could be the possible benefits of these symptoms in aiding recovery?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased appetite and thirst to replenish nutrients

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced energy towards fighting infection

options.label: C
options.text: Slowing down bacteria growth, channeling energy towards fighting infection, and starving bacteria of essential iron

options.label: D
options.text: Reducing the production of cytokines and prostaglandin

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the vagus nerve in the immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: To transmit information from the immune system to the brain stem

options.label: B
options.text: To produce cytokines to recruit immune cells

options.label: C
options.text: To destroy viruses and infected cells

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate body temperature

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of cytokines and prostaglandin on the brain's higher structures?

options.label: A
options.text: They increase the production of neurotransmitters

options.label: B
options.text: They have no impact on the brain's higher structures

options.label: C
options.text: They disrupt the activity of neurotransmitters, affecting emotions and reasoning

options.label: D
options.text: They reduce the production of macrophages

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of the discomfort experienced during illness?

options.label: A
options.text: The infection itself

options.label: B
options.text: The body's immune response

options.label: C
options.text: The lack of nutrients and water

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of autoimmune diseases

multiple-choice.question: A person is experiencing irritable mood, sadness, and confusion due to the flu. What could be the possible explanation for these emotional changes?

options.label: A
options.text: The flu virus is directly affecting the brain

options.label: B
options.text: The immune response is disrupting the activity of neurotransmitters

options.label: C
options.text: The person is experiencing dehydration

options.label: D
options.text: The person is not getting enough sleep

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the immune system launching a stronger attack to fight infection?

options.label: A
options.text: The infection spreads further into the blood and vital organs

options.label: B
options.text: The body experiences unpleasant symptoms such as fever and aches

options.label: C
options.text: The immune system becomes weaker

options.label: D
options.text: The body becomes more susceptible to autoimmune diseases

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of prostaglandin E2 in the immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: To increase appetite and thirst

options.label: C
options.text: To gear up the hypothalamus for war, causing a rise in body temperature and other symptoms

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the production of cytokines

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of the immune system treating normal bodily cues as threats?

options.label: A
options.text: The body becomes more resistant to infections

options.label: B
options.text: The body experiences unpleasant symptoms such as fever and aches

options.label: C
options.text: The body attacks itself, leading to autoimmune diseases

options.label: D
options.text: The immune system becomes weaker
